questions.text: __________ represents an entity in the real world that can be distinctly identified.
_______ is a template that defines objects of the same type.
An object is an instance of a __________.
The keyword __________ is required to define a class.
If TestCircle.java in Listing 9.1 is compiled successfully, __________.
________ is invoked to create an object.

choices.label: C
choices.text: A method with a return type

choices.label: D
choices.text: A method with the void return type

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Multiple constructors can be defined in a class.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Constructors do not have a return type, not even void.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Constructors must have the same name as the class itself.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Constructors are invoked using the new operator when an object is created.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code.

class TempClass {
  int i;
  public void TempClass(int j) {
    int i = j;
  }
}

public class C {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    TempClass temp = new TempClass(2);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because TempClass does not have a default constructor.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because TempClass does not have a constructor with an int argument.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program compiles fine, but it does not run because class C is not public.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A default constructor is provided automatically if no constructors are explicitly defined in the class.

choices.label: B
choices.text: At least one constructor must always be defined explicitly.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Every class has a default constructor.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The default constructor is a no-arg constructor.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code:

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    A a = new A();
    a.print();
  }
}

class A {
  String s;

  A(String s) {
    this.s = s;
  }

  void print() {
    System.out.println(s);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because class A is not a public class.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because class A does not have a default constructor.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine and prints nothing.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program would compile and run if you change A a = new A() to A a = new A("5").

questions.text: Given the declaration Circle x = new Circle(), which of the following statements is most accurate.

choices.label: B
choices.text: x contains an object of the Circle type.

choices.label: C
choices.text: x contains a reference to a Circle object.

choices.label: D
choices.text: You can assign an int value to x.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are correct?

choices.label: A
choices.text: A reference variable is an object.

choices.label: B
choices.text: A reference variable references to an object.

choices.label: C
choices.text: A data field in a class must be of a primitive type.

choices.label: D
choices.text: A data field in a class can be of an object type.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code.

public class Test {
  int x;

  public Test(String t) {
     System.out.println("Test");
  }

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Test test = new Test();
    System.out.println(test.x);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because System.out.println method cannot be invoked from the constructor.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because x has not been initialized.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because you cannot create an object from the class that defines the object.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a compile error because Test does not have a default constructor.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code.

public class Test {
  int x;
  
  public Test(String t) {
     System.out.println("Test");
  }

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Test test = null;
    System.out.println(test.x);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because test is not initialized.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because x has not been initialized.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because you cannot create an object from the class that defines the object.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program has a compile error because Test does not have a default constructor.

choices.label: E
choices.text: The program has a runtime NullPointerException because test is null while executing test.x.

questions.text: The default value for data field of a boolean type, numeric type, object type is ___________, respectively.
Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Local variables do not have default values.

choices.label: C
choices.text: A variable of a primitive type holds a value of the primitive type.

choices.label: D
choices.text: A variable of a reference type holds a reference to where an object is stored in the memory.

choices.label: E
choices.text: You may assign an int value to a reference variable.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code:

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    double radius;
    final double PI = 3.15169;
    double area = radius * radius * PI;
    System.out.println("Area is " + area);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has compile errors because the variable radius is not initialized.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program has a compile error because a constant PI is defined inside a method.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has no compile errors but will get a runtime error because radius is not initialized.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine.

questions.text:
Which of the following creates an object of the Date class:

A:
public class Test {
  public Test() {
    new java.util.Date();
  }
}

B:
public class Test {
  public Test() {
    java.util.Date date = new java.util.Date();
  }
}
Which of the following statements are correct?

choices.label: A
choices.text: When creating a Random object, you have to specify the seed or use the default seed.

choices.label: B
choices.text: If two Random objects have the same seed, the sequence of the random numbers obtained from these two objects are identical.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The nextInt() method in the Random class returns the next random int value.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The nextDouble() method in the Random class returns the next random double value.

questions.text: To obtain the distance between the points (40, 50) and (5.5, 4.4), use _________.
A method that is associated with an individual object is called __________.

What is the output of the second println statement in the main method?

public class Foo {
  int i;
  static int s;

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Foo f1 = new Foo();
    System.out.println("f1.i is " + f1.i + " f1.s is " + f1.s);
    Foo f2 = new Foo();
    System.out.println("f2.i is " + f2.i + " f2.s is " + f2.s);
    Foo f3 = new Foo();
    System.out.println("f3.i is " + f3.i + " f3.s is " + f3.s);
  }

  public Foo() {
    i++;
    s++;
  }
}

What code may be filled in the blank without causing syntax or runtime errors:

public class Test {
  java.util.Date date;

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Test test = new Test();
    System.out.println(_________________);
  }
}

You should add the static keyword in the place of ? in Line ________ in the following code:

Line  1 public class Test { 
Line  2   private int age;
Line  3 
Line  4   public ? int square(int n) { 
Line  5     return n * n;
Line  6   }
Line  7
Line  8   public ? int getAge() {
Line  9     return age;
Line 10   }
Line 11 }
To declare a constant MAX_LENGTH as a member of the class, you write

Analyze the following code.

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int n = 2;
    xMethod(n);
           
    System.out.println("n is " + n);
  }

  void xMethod(int n) {
    n++;
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The code has a compile error because xMethod does not return a value.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The code has a compile error because xMethod is not declared static.

questions.text:
What is the output of the third println statement in the main method?

public class Foo {
  int i;
  static int s;

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Foo f1 = new Foo();
    System.out.println("f1.i is " + f1.i + " f1.s is " + f1.s);
    Foo f2 = new Foo();
    System.out.println("f2.i is " + f2.i + " f2.s is " + f2.s);
    Foo f3 = new Foo();
    System.out.println("f3.i is " + f3.i + " f3.s is " + f3.s);
  }

  public Foo() {
    i++;
    s++;
  }
}

Suppose the xMethod() is invoked in the following constructor in a class, xMethod() is _________ in the class.

public MyClass() {
  xMethod();
}

choices.label: C
choices.text: a static method or an instance method

questions.text:
Suppose the xMethod() is invoked from a main method in a class as follows, xMethod() is _________ in the class.

public static void main(String[] args) {
  xMethod();
}

choices.label: C
choices.text: a static method or an instance method

questions.text: Variables that are shared by every instance of a class are __________.

Analyze the following code:

public class Test {
  public static void main(String args[]) {
    NClass nc = new NClass();
    nc.t = nc.t++;
  }
}

class NClass {
  int t;
  private NClass() {
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because the NClass class has a private constructor.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program does not compile because the parameter list of the main method is wrong.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program compiles, but has a runtime error because t has no initial value.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code:

public class Test {
  private int t;

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int x;
    System.out.println(t);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The variable t is not initialized and therefore causes errors.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The variable t is private and therefore cannot be accessed in the main method.

choices.label: C
choices.text: t is non-static and it cannot be referenced in a static context in the main method.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The variable x is not initialized and therefore causes errors.

choices.label: E
choices.text: The program compiles and runs fine.

questions.text:
Analyze the following code and choose the best answer:

public class Foo {
  private int x;

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Foo foo = new Foo();
    System.out.println(foo.x);
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: Since x is private, it cannot be accessed from an object foo.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Since x is defined in the class Foo, it can be accessed by any method inside the class without using an object. You can write the code to access x without creating an object such as foo in this code.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Since x is an instance variable, it cannot be directly used inside a main method. However, it can be accessed through an object such as foo in this code.

choices.label: D
choices.text: You cannot create a self-referenced object; that is, foo is created inside the class Foo.

questions.text: To prevent a class from being instantiated, _____________________

choices.label: A
choices.text: don't use any modifiers on the constructor.

choices.label: B
choices.text: use the public modifier on the constructor.

choices.label: C
choices.text: use the private modifier on the constructor.

choices.label: D
choices.text: use the static modifier on the constructor.

questions.text: Which is the advantage of encapsulation?

choices.label: B
choices.text: Making the class final causes no consequential changes to other code.

choices.label: C
choices.text: It enables changes to the implementation without changing a class's contract and causes no consequential changes to other code.

choices.label: D
choices.text: It enables changes to a class's contract without changing the implementation and causes no consequential changes to other code.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Use the private modifier to encapsulate data fields.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Encapsulating data fields makes the program easy to maintain.

choices.label: C
choices.text: Encapsulating data fields makes the program short.

choices.label: D
choices.text: Encapsulating data fields helps prevent programming errors.

questions.text: Suppose you wish to provide an accessor method for a boolean property finished, what should the signature of this method?
Encapsulation means ______________.

choices.label: A
choices.text: that data fields should be declared private

choices.label: B
choices.text: that a class can extend another class

choices.label: C
choices.text: that a variable of supertype can refer to a subtype object

choices.label: D
choices.text: that a class can contain another class

questions.text:
What is the value of myCount.count displayed?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Count myCount = new Count();
    int times = 0;

    for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)
      increment(myCount, times);

    System.out.println(
      "myCount.count = " + myCount.count);
    System.out.println("times = "+ times);
  }

  public static void increment(Count c, int times) {
    c.count++;
    times++;
  }
}

class Count {
  int count;

  Count(int c) {
    count = c;
  }

  Count() {
    count = 1;
  }
}

What is the value of times displayed?

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Count myCount = new Count();
    int times = 0;

    for (int i = 0; i < 100; i++)
      increment(myCount, times);

    System.out.println(
      "myCount.count = " + myCount.count);
    System.out.println("times = "+ times);
  }

  public static void increment(Count c, int times) {
    c.count++;
    times++;
  }
}

class Count {
  int count;

  Count(int c) {
    count = c;
  }

  Count() {
    count = 1;
  }
}

What is the output of the following program?

import java.util.Date;

public class Test {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Date date = new Date(1234567);
    m1(date);
    System.out.print(date.getTime() + " ");

    m2(date);
    System.out.println(date.getTime());
  }

  public static void m1(Date date) {
    date = new Date(7654321);
  }

  public static void m2(Date date) {
    date.setTime(7654321);
  }
}
When invoking a method with an object argument, ___________ is passed.

choices.label: D
choices.text: the object is copied, then the reference of the copied object

questions.text: Given the declaration Circle[] x = new Circle[10], which of the following statements is most accurate?

choices.label: A
choices.text: x contains an array of ten int values.

choices.label: B
choices.text: x contains an array of ten objects of the Circle type.

choices.label: C
choices.text: x contains a reference to an array and each element in the array can hold a reference to a Circle object.

choices.label: D
choices.text: x contains a reference to an array and each element in the array can hold a Circle object.

questions.text: Assume java.util.Date[] dates = new java.util.Date[10], which of the following statements are true?

choices.label: C
choices.text: dates = new java.util.Date[5] is fine, which assigns a new array to dates.

choices.label: D
choices.text: dates = new Date() is fine, which creates a new Date object and assigns to dates.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true about an immutable object?

choices.label: A
choices.text: The contents of an immutable object cannot be modified.

choices.label: B
choices.text: All properties of an immutable object must be private.

choices.label: C
choices.text: All properties of an immutable object must be of primitive types.

choices.label: D
choices.text: A readable object type property in an immutable object must also be immutable.

choices.label: E
choices.text: An immutable object contains no mutator methods.

questions.text:
What is the output for the first print statement in the main method?

public class Foo {
  static int i = 0;
  static int j = 0;

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int i = 2;
    int k = 3;
    {
      int j = 3;
      System.out.println("i + j is " + i + j);
    }

    k = i + j;
    System.out.println("k is " + k);
    System.out.println("j is " + j);
  }
}

What is the output for the second print statement in the main method?

public class Foo {
  static int i = 0;
  static int j = 0;

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int i = 2;
    int k = 3;
    {
      int j = 3;
      System.out.println("i + j is " + i + j);
    }

    k = i + j;
    System.out.println("k is " + k);
    System.out.println("j is " + j);
  }
}

What is the output for the third print statement in the main method?

public class Foo {
  static int i = 0;
  static int j = 0;

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    int i = 2;
    int k = 3;
    {
      int j = 3;
      System.out.println("i + j is " + i + j);
    }

    k = i + j;
    System.out.println("k is " + k);
    System.out.println("j is " + j);
  }
}
You can declare two variables with the same name in __________.

choices.label: A
choices.text: a method, one as a formal parameter and the other as a local variable

choices.label: C
choices.text: two nested blocks in a method (two nested blocks means one being inside the other)

questions.text:
Analyze the following code:

class Circle {
  private double radius;
  
  public Circle(double radius) {
    radius = radius;
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: The program has a compile error because it does not have a main method.

choices.label: B
choices.text: The program will compile, but you cannot create an object of Circle with a specified radius. The object will always have radius 0.

choices.label: C
choices.text: The program has a compile error because you cannot assign radius to radius.

choices.label: D
choices.text: The program does not compile because Circle does not have a default constructor.

questions.text:
Which of the following can be placed in the blank line in the following code?

public class Test {
  private int id;
  
  public void m1() {
    _____.id = 45;
  }
}

Analyze the following code:

class Test {
  private double i;
  
  public Test(double i) {
    this.t();
    this.i = i;
  }

  public Test() {
    System.out.println("Default constructor");
    this(1);
  }

  public void t() {
    System.out.println("Invoking t");
  }
}

choices.label: A
choices.text: this.t() may be replaced by t().

choices.label: B
choices.text: this.i may be replaced by i.

choices.label: C
choices.text: this(1) must be called before System.out.println("Default constructor").

choices.label: D
choices.text: this(1) must be replaced by this(1.0).
